awd_titl_txt: Workshop Proposal: Student Research Workshop at AMTA-2010
awd_abstract_narration:
NSF is providing partial financial support for a Student Research Workshop 
at the AMTA-2010 conference in Denver, Colorado. The Association for Machine 
Translation in the Americas (AMTA) is a non-profit professional organization 
in the area of Machine Translation (MT) in the US and the American continent. 
The main mission of AMTA is to facilitate and promote the exchange of 
knowledge and information between the communities of researchers, developers 
and users of Machine Translation and related translation technologies. In its 
effort to foster the professional growth of the next generation of MT 
researchers, AMTA-2010 is featuring a Student Research Workshop, embedded 
as an integral part of the research program at the conference. Students at 
all levels of study (undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate) are invited to 
submit papers describing their research work. NSF is providing funding to 
subsidize travel, conference and accommodation expenses for up to 10 students 
that have been selected to present their research work at the workshop. 

The AMTA-2010 Student Research Workshop will greatly facilitate professional 
growth for the brightest young researchers in the field of MT, in the early 
stages of their professional career. The workshop will contribute to the 
professional development of a skilled and diverse workforce in the area of 
Machine Translation and computational processing of natural language. MT and 
other language processing applications are becoming vital technologies in the 
global information age. Strength in these areas is crucial to American 
competitiveness in the global economy of the 21st century.

Organizational Partners

Association for Machine Translation in the Americas (AMTA)

The student workshop was held on November 1, 2010, as part of the 2010 biennial conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas (AMTA).  The student workshop was an integral part of the conference program.  AMTA took care of all logistics associated with the workshop.  This grant, awarded to CMU, provided financial support for student participation in the workshop. AMTA was responsible for processing all student expense reports and reimbursements for the participating students. CMU reimbursed AMTA for these expenses based on a detailed invoice submitted by AMTA. Final accounting between AMTA and CMU was completed in January 2012.

Training and Development:

This NSF grant provided partial financial support for a Student Research Workshop that was held on November 1, 2010, at the AMTA-2010 conference in Denver, Colorado.  The Association for Machine Translation in the Americas (AMTA) is a non-profit professional organization in the area of Machine Translation (MT) in the US and the American continent. The main mission of AMTA is to facilitate and promote the exchange of knowledge and information between the communities of researchers, developers and users of Machine Translation and related translation technologies. In an effort to foster the professional growth of the next generation of MT researchers, AMTA-2010 featured a Student Research Workshop, which was embedded as an integral part of the research program at the conference.  Students at all levels of study (undergraduate, graduate and post-graduate) were invited to submit papers describing their research work. A program committee consisting of both students and well-known researchers in the area of MT reviewed submissions to the workshop. The committee was headed by two student co-chairs, with Stephan Vogel (PI of this grant) serving as Faculty Advisor. The workshop received a total of seven submissions, of which four were accepted for presentation at the workshop.  NSF funding support subsidized conference participation expenses for the four students that were competitively selected to present their research work at the workshop. Financial support was also provided to cover the expenses of the two student co-chairs of the workshop and an invited speaker at the workshop.

The following is the list of students that were supported:

Student Research Workshop Co-chairs:

- Steve DeNeefe, University of Southern California

- Nguyen Bach, Carnegie Mellon University

Student Presenters at the Workshop:

- Kfir Bar, Tel Aviv University

- Reshef Shilon, Tel Aviv University

- Thoudam Doren Singh, Jadavpur University

- Hwidong Na, Pohang University of Science and Technology (POSTECH)

Invited Speaker at the workshop:

-          Richard Zens, Google

The research papers presented by the four selected students were of high quality. The discussions held at the workshop were very helpful to the students. 

Books or Other One-time Publications

Thoudam Doren Singh and Savaji Bandyopadhyay. Statistical Machine Translation of English – Manipuri using Morpho-syntactic and Semantic Information.  In Proceedings of the Student Research Workshop at the Ninth Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas, Denver, Colorado, November 2010.

Hwidong Na, Jin-Ji Li, Yeha Lee and Jong-hyeok Lee.  A Synchronous Context Free Grammar using Dependency Sequence for Syntax-based Statistical Machine Translation.  In Proceedings of the Student Research Workshop at the Ninth Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas, Denver, Colorado, November 2010.

Kfir Bar and Nachum Dershowitz. Using Synonyms for Arabic-to-English Example-Based Translation.  In Proceedings of the Student Research Workshop at the Ninth Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas, Denver, Colorado, November 2010.

Reshef Shilon, Nizar Habash, Alon Lavie and Shuly Wintner. Machine Translation between Hebrew and Arabic: Needs, Challenges and Preliminary Solutions.  In Proceedings of the Student Research Workshop at the Ninth Conference of the Association for Machine Translation in the Americas, Denver, Colorado, November 2010.

Contributions to Human Resource Development:

 The AMTA-2010 Student Research Workshop greatly facilitated professional growth for bright young researchers in the field of MT, in the early stages of their professional career. The workshop contributed to the professional development of a skilled and diverse workforce in the area of Machine Translation and computational processing of natural language.   MT and other language processing applications are becoming vital technologies in the global information age. Strength in these areas is crucial to American competitiveness in the global economy of the 21st century.
